Probst fully agreed, and repeated that he was convinced that this whole problem
of what policy instructions should be given Harley in negotiating with the
Iron and Steel Institute was the responsibility of the Adult Education Committee
Siegel stated that he was in favor of the revolving fund for program production,
and reiterated his conviction that the decision on such a matter was a respon¬
sibility of the NAEB Board. Harley asked what, in the light of this discussion,
he was supposed to ask for in the negotiations with the Iron and Steel Institute
Wheatley moved to amend Hullf3 original motion to read that Harley should nego¬
tiate with the Iron and Steel Institute nto recover program production costs
and additional costs as necessary to serve the mutual interests of both groups."
The amended motion was agreed to as the directive for Harley. Harley is to
report back to the Adult Education Committee on the results of the negotiations.
The question of release dates for publicity and for the shows was then dis¬
cussed. Harley stated that it had been suggested that all four series be
released at the same time. Wheatley thought that the Jefferson series should
be released in May, even with the possibility of a hiatus after four shows,
since he thought this would be a help to Fletcher. Siegel and Hull thought
that a June release would be better from a publicity point of view. Siegel
thought that the Jefferson series should be released first, although only one
show in the series needed to be aired before releasing the USSR series. Hull
said that perhaps the four shows already done could be released on June 1 so
that a summer trial run could be made. Siegel moved that as many Jefferson pro¬
grams as possible be released to as many NAEB stations available the week of
June 1. This was agreed to. Miles questioned whether we still intended to
follow the release plan approved at the December meeting. It was decided to
release only to NAEB stations at this time with more to come later when a mass
duplicator is installed or the Iron and Steel Institute make pressings available
INTERNATIONAL UNDERSTANDING; Harley said that under the present plan, each of
the five consultants are to be personally responsible for one show, and that
each would appear on that show. It is hoped that all production on the five
shows can be done during April. Plans for all shows are in, and one script is
completed. Production on this script is set for April 7.
Siegel moved that the USSR series be released to as many NAEB stations as are
available during the week of June 15, but that no shows or publicity on the
shows should be released until the Adult Education Committee has heard all
five shows*
Wheatley thought the USSR series should be tied in some way with the idea of
the adult education of the American voter. Hull suggested that a presidential
candidate might appear on each show. Probst was against tying in that closely
with election politics. Siegel suggested that the shows might be released so
that a station could play all five during one week. Wheatley thought that
was a good idea if you followed up by repeating them on a one-a-week basis,
^robst said that release on June 15 would be bad in that we could get little
publicity on them at that time due to the political conventions. He felt they
should be released in the Fall. A vote was taken on the Siegel motion that
the USSR series be released during the week of June 15. The motion was agreed
to with Probst dissenting.
